newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Educators alarmed as keyring-size craze sweeps HK.
newsitem.headline: Educators alarmed as keyring-size craze sweeps HK.

text.p: A key problem gripping Hong Kong before Chinese rule in two weeks' time isn't the economy or Sino-British squabbling -- but an electronic egg from the Land of the Rising Sun.

The Japanese-made "virtual pet", Tamagotchi, is sweeping Hong Kong, with fans paying high prices for the keyring-sized computer game, which "grows to a kind of chicken" if the right buttons are pushed.
Educators and pyschologists have expressed fears that the "death" of a virtual pet will traumatise young children and affect their mental development.
Counselling has been ordered for grieving youngsters.
But a new Tamagotchi game on sale next month, featuring a young triad gangster hero, is set to heighten their concerns.
The owner needs to feed cigarettes and alcohol to this variant "pet" so it matures as a triad (secret society) member. A knife fight is an optional extra.
The new game is based on a popular weekly local comic, Young Triads, chronicling the adventures and sexual exploits of its narrator Chan Ho-nam.
The original comic can only be sold to adults. It is not clear whether the new Tamagotchi will be off-limit to those under 18.
But educators have already called on the government to ban the new game.
The electronic egg, also popular in Japan, hit Hong Kong three months ago. The suggested retail price is HK$150 (US$19) but has since rocketed up to HK$3,000 (US$387) a piece.
Many schools in the territory have banned the Tamagotchi after many students were found playing it during lessons.
The virtual pets require 24-hour attention or they can "die" easily. Many schoolchildren rear their pets even during school lessons.
But educators worry that children did not know how to cope with the death of their "pets".
As a result the Education Department and non-prfit organisations have decided to provide counselling for pupils unable to deal with the loss.
Counsellors will also help students upset becuse they cannot rear their "pets" during school hours.
But all is not completely lost when the pets die. They can be buried on the Internet and a home page, the Virtual Graveyard for Your Beloved Tamagotchi, on the World Wide Web.
